Calling the Task Force on the
Human Climate "a good idea,"
President Steven Muller said that
the University's imperative was
to institutionalize the process of
communication concerning ethics
at Hopkins.
In a wide-ranging News-Letter
interview, Muller claimed that
whereas the administration should
"continue to take a lead" in this
discussion, it found a need for
communication among students,
faculty, and staff.
The Task Force report, which
is due out soon, addresses a
number of Homewood concerns,
including the ethics issue. Muller
discussed ethics at Hopkins in a
broad sense, stressing the need
for discussion about race and sex
issues as well.
Although encouraging students
to take an active role in forthcoming discussions, Muller warned
that joint discussion would prove
more effective. He said, "A
grievance does no good unless it
is shared with people who can
carry out the suggestion."
Muller said that Vice President
for Institutional Affairs Jakie Hall
is "the person to keep [the discussion] going." Muller added that
Hall, who is responsible for the
Task Force, is "very good at
opening people up."
Muller said that students would
have to take a leading role in the
reinstitution of an honor code for
Homewood. Asserting that the
topic is "important enough to
warrant discussion," he implied
a less active role to be played by
the administration.

"Clearly it was not working.
he claimed, refering to the honor
code that was repealed fifteen
years ago. Muller said he would
be pleased with an honor code,
because any honor system "tells
a lot about ourselves." Referring
to the advantages of the honor
code, he said that "nobody can
persuade students of that except
the students themselves."
Muller went on to evaluate current steps students are taking in
the pursuit of a new honor code.

Council attacks CUS proposal
to change add/drop deadlines
by Tom McNamara
At Wednesday's meeting, the
Student Council discussed a proposal brought before the Committee on Undergraduate Studies to
change the deadline for adding
courses from eight weeks into the
semester to two.
Also in the proposal are recommendations to advance the
deadline for dropping courses
from eight weeks into the
semester to six, and abandoning
the "WD" notation currently put
on transcripts if a student were to
drop a course after eight but
before eleven weeks into the
semester.
The new policy would require
students to continue in their
courses and receive grades once
six weeks had passed, although

the deadline for changing to or
from pass/fail grading in classes
would be moved back from four
weeks into the semester to six.
CUS members David Hannan
and Lora Sims said that the
associate dean of the School of
Arts and Sciences, P. Kyle
McCarter Jr., suggested that the
CUS adopt these changes.
Although sharply divided on
the proper course of action to be
taken in opposing the proposal,
an overwhelming majority of
members strongly objected to the
proposed deadlines.
Student Council President Scott
FitzGerald, Sims, and others expressed their desire to hear the
opinions of concerned students
and suggested that anyone interested attend next week's Council meeting. In addition,

FitzGerald said,"We will invite
the deans who are involved."
Sims added that the Housing
Committee meeting held in the
SC office Wednesday at 7 p.m.
would include discussion of the
issue if those who attend are interested in discussing the matter.
McCarter had cited abuse of
the current system as the most
pressing reason for the administration's concern with the
issue, according to Sims.
Describing herself as a "devil's
advocate," Sims explained the
position of those in favor of
McCarter's proposal.

the administration believe that
some students now use the system

Soviet philosopher
asserts we cannot
achieve peace by
threatening war
by James Frost
Soviet philosophers are currently facing "hard times in the
USSR" because of changes in
cultural, philosophical, and
political thinking since 1985,
claimed Vladimir Mshvenieradze
to a crowd of twenty students and
professors Monday.
Mshvenieradze is the deputy
director of the Institute of
Philosophy at the Soviet
Academy of Sciences. He spoke
in
the
Department
of
Philosophy's seminar room,
along with Soviet philosopher
Boris Grushin, as part of a
philosophical exchange group in
the United States.
Three more Soviet philosophers were scheduled to
speak, according to Department
of Philosophy Chairman Jerome
Schneewind, who organized the
seminar. Their flights, however,
were unexpectedly late, he said,
so they flew directly to
Washington, D.C.
Schneewind said, "About a
year ago, a group of American
philosophers, eight of us, went to
the Soviet Union to hold discussions on justice and liberty with
members of the Institute of
Philosophy at the Soviet
Academy of Sciences. We are
now witnessing the beginning of
the Soviet visit to the United
States."
Mshvenieradze said that he and
his colleagues had tried to be
critical of the papers presented by
the American philosophers, but
found so much in common with
regard to thoughts on justice and
freedom.
"Free society is not something
given by God, but something that
the individuals must create,"he
said. "Every type of society has
its own understanding of freedom
and justice."
He added that man is forced to
look at freedom and justice in a
drastically new way in the nuclear
age. "The Roman way of getting
peace does not work today, "he
said. "We cannot have peace by
threatening war.
"Freedom and justice are as
old as when the first human being first started to think, " he
said. "The type of justice and
freedom always depended on the
type of society."
Mshvenieradze claimed to
agree with his American colleagues on three main points.
First, "justice can be understood
as the proper balance between
liberty and equality." Second,
"justice has to protect freedom."
Finally, "we have to come to a
common understanding of
justice."
He strongly differed with the
American philosophers by making three further points.
First, he declared that the
topics of justice and freedom
should be viewed "from all possible sides,"including economic,

judicial, political, psychological,
and social.
Second, he claimed that justice
and freedom must be applied to
every individual in society. "It
should not be a freedom and
justice for elite, " he said. "It
should be freedom and justice for
everybody absolutely everybody.,
Third, he insisted that although
we must "still have in mind that
theory and history are indispensible, we cannot elaborate a good
theory only by theoretical
analysis of previous theories. We
should always test our theory
upon reality."

college and university presidents have named

in America, according to U.S. News & World
Report's third biennial survey of American higher
education released today.

schools providing the "best" undergraduate

same category as their own.

categories based on the 1987 classification of
institutions of higher education assembled by the
Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of
Teaching in Princeton, N.J. Presidents were requested to take into consideration cohesiveness
of curriculum, quality of teaching, relationship
between faculty and students and the atmosphere of learning fostered by the campus.

Maintaining Policy
A proposal was brought before the Committee on Undergraduate Studies(CUS)and
discussed at Student Council this week
which makes changes to the present
Add/Drop policy. According to the nowexistent policy, students may add or drop
classes up until the eighth week of the
semester.
The proposed new policy would move
the add deadline to the second week of the
semester, and drop date would be moved
to the sixth week. This drastic change, supported by Associate Dean of Arts and
Sciences P. Kyle McCarter, was offered in
an attempt to keep some students from using the present system to control their grade
point averages and reserving space in more
classes than their schedules allow.
The Council has developed a counterproposal in response to this. Although it is
only a tentative one, this proposal offers an
add deadline even later than the one
presently in effect. Council members
believe that their plan would be more effective than McCarter's because it would
allow students to fill the spaces left in certain classes after the final drop deadline.
While the Council's proposal needs some

refinements, its principle certainly addresses the needs of student more appropriately than McCarter's.
Many students attend classes unofficially until places become available; sometimes
this is not until four or five weeks into the
semester— often after the first midterm. A
two-week dealine is a restrictively early
one. It would permanently close students
out of classes long before others had to drop
them; by the same token, it would keep
students from dropping classes if they had
no possibility of adding other classes. In the
long run, it would limit some of the flexibility students enjoy early in the year.
Student Council President Scott FitzGerald encouraged students to attend next
Wednesday's Council meeting and express
their opinions about McCarter's proposal.
If the Council's overwhelming disapproval
of the plan is indicative of student opinions
in general, then we hope FitzGerald will
have a solid turnout on Wednesday. It is
imperative that McCarter and the Administration hear the students' views before
they make such a critical change in the
undergraduate program.

A Look at Numbers
The soon to be released U.S. News &
World Report survey of college presidents
shows that Hopkins has been ranked sixteenth in its category, national universities.
The ranking is surprisingly indicative of
Hopkins. It suggests the good and the bad,
but most of all it tries to correlate and quantify Hopkins' uniqueness.
While Hopkins is extremely wellrespected nationally in a number of fields,
the criteria evaluated shed light on why the
ranking is, in comparison to some of these
programs, quite low. The college presidents
were asked to take into consideration the
cohesiveness of the curriculum, the quality of teaching, the relationship between
faculty and students, and the atmosphere
of learning fostered by the campus.
These are the kinds of topics with which
Hopkins undergrads are notoriously discontent. Regarding in particular the faculty's
concern, manifested in time and attitude,
for students, undergraduates have
substantial—and valid—complaints.
The problems regarding faculty/student
relationships and curriculum are being addressed. P. Kyle McCarter Jr., the
associate dean of the School of Arts and
Sciences, is responsible for an intensive

department self-evaluation to take place this
year. Despite the apparent idealism of the
suggestion, this quantified interpretation of
our performance in the given criteria might
provide an impetus. Hopkins, by taking the
ranking for various programs as seriously
as it does, might learn to take great pride
in any future escalation in the ranks.
The ranking of sixteen falls in a range
that reflects a dichotomy. Considering the
problems in curriculum and student/faculty relations that are so apparent, the ranking is still quite high.
A somewhat legitimate response is that
Hopkins is ranked so high because other institutions in its category face comparable
problems and limitations. Although this
thought answers the question somewhat, it
avoids Hopkins' attitude toward education.
Hopkins' strength lies in its independent
study opportunities. Those opportunities,
including the ability to work on an individual basis with faculty starting freshman
year, are by far more abundant than
students realize.
The ranking, which is both high and yet
not high enough, brings out the strengths
in Hopkins. A surprisingly astute survey,
if we pay attention to the numbers.

geeks . . .happy singing!

Fall Fest '87 feelings
by Brooke A. Ettle
"Except for the weather, I'm
definitely pleased," said InterFraternity Council President
Steven Basta about last Sunday's
Fall Fest, a day of free food and
music. The Fall Fest, which took
place under rainy afternoon skies
on the Gilman quad, was designed to keep students on campus
over the Fall Break weekend.
Despite poor attendance in the
past, Fall Fest I-987 was successful in attracting the student
population, predominantly upperclassmen, for various
reasons—some of which had little to do with Fall Fest itself.
The format of Fall Fest was the
most influential factor in its success this year. Organizers of the
event from the Hop,IFC and StuStudents enjoy themselves at the Fall Break Festival last weekend. Attendees ate, drank and listendent Council kept the afternoon
ed to bands among other activities offered.
completely unstructured so that
students could come and go at
their leisure. "We had to do
something for Fall Fest," said
Student Council President Scott
Fitzgerald, "and this was the best
idea because people can come and
go when they want without being
obligated to stay for certain
activities."
The casual format of Fall Fest,
however, was unsettling to certain freshmen used to the planned activities of Orientation.
"Where are the activities?" asked freshman Josh Putterman.
"What's there to do besides stand
here and freeze?"
Early afternoon rains and low
temperatures discouraged some
students from attending the event.

"It's too cold for me," said
Gabrielle Kirsch. "I didn't feel
like standing outside doing
nothing while I froze to death."
As the skies cleared and
temperatures rose later in the
afternoon, attendance did improve. "A lot of people were in
doubt as to whether this was going on or not with the weather
like it is," said ATO brother Jeff
Perlstein. "Since the weather has
cleared up though, more people
have stopped by."
The proximity of certain
religious holidays had an indirect
effect on the attendance at the
event. Said freshman Jonathan
Kurtz, "Many students have been
away for Rosh Hashana, Yom
Kippur, and Succot which took
place just this past week. Now a
lot of us want to be back here this
weekend to see our friends and to
see Fall Fest." FitzGerald was
equally enthusiastic about the
popularity of the event. "I know
people who came back to the
campus [on Saturday] just to see
this," he said. "A lot of people
were really looking forward to
this."
Basta was quick to add that the
workload and upcoming midterms did not adversely affect the
turnout at Fall Fest. "Students •
might just have easily gone home
to catch up on their work," he
said. "They would have gone
home too if it weren't for this.
Fall Fest is designed to be a time
when students can relax and take
a break from their work. I think
a lot of students stayed here and
took advantage of it."

PEDAL, from 12
is mainly responsible for
organizing and publicizing
Club rides. The iconoclastic
Cycle
newsletter,
Killers,keeps members abreast
of club developments. The
Club still has a need for a
masseuse. Any one interested
in this position should get in
touch with Gurland.
The vitality of the Club is a
testament to its members enthusiasm. The original Bike
Club became defunct in 1984
after a senior president
absconded with the equipment. The dedication and
perserverence shown by
Anne-Marie Ulrich, Dan
Ninigrin, and Aaron Davis in
the fall of 1985 helped ressurrect a new cycling club. With
the purchase of new equipment(and the establishment of
a security ID system) club
membership flourished. By the
spring of last year, weekend
rides that originally produced
two or three riders were attended by ten or more. At present, the Club's Saturday rides
are a pot-luck, with each
cyclist meeting another and
deciding where they would
like to go. On Sunday, maps
detailing rides of approximately 10,20, and 35 miles are
distributed and the riders split
into groups.
"It's difficult at times to
find the perfect ride for
everyone," says Davis, "but
we try to see to it that no one
gets lost and that everyone has
fun."
When the weather gets chilly, club members still turn out
for the twelve o'clock bell.
With the same dogged dedication (or blatent stupidity)
displayed by the Crew Team
and their five a.m. sculling
sessions, Club members face
wind-chill factors that would
send polar bears running for
shelter, rain that would make
Noah build a little bit faster,
and canines that would make
Cujo look like a French Poodle. Complaints are never
heard though, just the hiss of
115 psi tires on very cold
pavement.
Although the Club includes
many tourists, its core is made
up of a few die-hard racers.
Last weekend at 6 a.m., as the
rest of the sane world slept,
Hopkins Cycling Club
members were congregating at
MSE, shivering as they loaded their thoroughbreds onto
car-racks. Hoping to cash in
on all those weekend rides,
they headed off for the Eastern
Shore Velo Club Cycling
Championship, a two day
stage race composed of a 32
mile road race on Saturday, a
6 mile time trial Sunday morning, and a 21 mile road race
Sunday afternoon.
Saturday's race was five circuits of a six mile loop. The
morning was cool, the road
rolling. Junior Kyu-Tae Lee
was strong throughout the
race, narrowly missing a few
primes (pronounced preems),

which are merchandise or
point prizes given to the winner of a certain lap. Lee faced
a strong sprinter in the final
lap, placing second in a photofinish. Senior Aaron Davis
followed Lee to take third
while senior Tim Reed took
sixth.
A time trial is a race against
the clock, the so-called "race
of truth." Sunday morning
Reed covered the still-dewy
course in a blistering 14:23, a
time which earned him second
place for that stage. Davis
finished fifth, a second behind
the fourth place finisher. Lee
also ran into some bad luck, as
his chain snapped at the turnaround point, sending him into the brush alongside the
road.
All riders seemed to be
recovered for the afternoon
race, as the Hopkins sky-blue
jersies never left the head of
the pack. Reed set the pace for
much of the race, leaving
Davis to sprint for the finish,
where, as Lee had done the,
day earlier, he took second by
half a wheel. Lee crossed the
line in fourth place.
The final results showed
Davis in third place overall,
and Lee in fourth. All in all,
the team had three second
place finishes, one third, one
fourth, and one fifth, a particularly strong showing for
the team's initial race. Juniors
Kendt Eckland and Jeff
Gurland had respectable showings, as did somphomore Udai
Kammula. Freshman Mark
Rubin ran into an amourous
terrier in Sunday's last race,
but escaped the incident
unscathed. All competitors enjoyed themselves, despite the
almost two-hour commute to
the Eastern Shore.
"We'll definitely be stronger
in the spring," said Reed after
the race. Coming up later this
month on the team's schedule
is the Tour of America
Criterium in College Park,
which will take place October
25. November will bring the
Bobby Phillips Criterium at
Lake Montebello, just a few
blocks past Memorial stadium.
The bulk of racing, however,
will take place in the spring.
The team will participate in as
many Eastern Collegiate Cycling Federation (which
Hopkins is a part of)events as
possible. Races are held at
various campuses in the Northeast. The ECCF championships will be held in Vermont
at the end of the season.
Whether racing or just
hanging out, the Bike Club
holds true to its motto: It's better to look good than to be
good. If you'd like to join the
blue-jersies for some high
speed thrills or a tour through
the Maryland countryside,
show up in front of MSE or
call Jeff Gurland. No experience is necessary. Come
out for a spin. The foliage will
be beautiful the next few
weeks and the spandex has
never been tighter!

Well, they tell me that the
theme for this issue is ethics, and
part of the ethics of this biz is letting somebody else talk for a
change—opposing viewpoints and
such. So, this week we have a
two-part column: First I ramble,
then we have tag-team reviewing
from two of our other staffers.
One of the albums I received to
review was the latest from
Samantha Fox, the British topless
model turned pop star. A quick
listen revealed nothing new—she
still has no talent. In fact, judging from the sleeve photos and
her lyrical choices("I Can't Get
No Satisfaction," etc.), it has
become quite obvious that the only thing selling this girl is her sex,
which she flaunts quite openly.
Now, this is the nature of the
beast—most girl groups have sold
more on their sex than their talent
(yes, there are exceptions), but
this makes me wonder if maybe
or Tipper doesn't have a point
about that demon rock-and-roll.
By selling themselves like this,
female rockers give a very skewed image to female sexuality.
Now, I have never considered
myself a feminist, but I do find
this is degrading to women. We
find ourselves casting women into
a mold created by these performers, and we expect them to

live up to these expectations—we
want hot nymphos, and that's
what we expect.
Okay, point two: I don't
believe for a minute that rockand-roll carbonates hormones any
more than a good-looking
member of the opposite sex, but
performers of this type sure do
put a lot of emphasis on the sex
act. This in itself might not be a
bad thing, but in this day and age,
emphasizing having sex with wild
abandon seems a bit stupid, considering all the stuff lurking out
there. It would be stupid for performers to start writing songs
about using condoms, but they
should, like any responsible artist, take a few minutes to consider what they're saying.
As for Samantha Fox and her
ilk, I can only conjecture that
they've decided to say something
blatently adolescent, and more
than a little stupid.

to be grasped in parts. At times
she is undaunted and Herculean,

Selecting plans for
student insurance
The first few weeks on a college campus are normally
hectic—students jam bookstores,
dorms are invaded and
classrooms must be located. But
there is one very important area
of college life that shouldn't be
overlooked by students during the
scramble—a health plan.
"Medical expenses can run extremely high, and many students
requiring services beyond the
scope of college health centers
will often find themselves with inadequate coverage," said Garry
Raim, director of marketing for
the Blue Cross and Blue Shield of
Maryland Student Health Plan.
According to the latest figures
available from the Health Insurance Association of America,
the average cost per day in a
hospital is $470. An accident or
illness resulting in a two-week
hospital stay could cost in excess
of $6,500. And if surgery is required, the medical bill would
climb even higher.
"Because someone is young
and healthy, the last thing they
are likely to worry about is health
care expenses," said Raim. "But
without quality health insurance
a student could face an unexpected hospital bill—a bill that
could pose a serious financial
setback."
itaim and other health professionals suggest several steps:
"First," he said,' it's important
for students to learn whether they
are protected from the high costs
of hospitalization, emergency and
surgical care."
He explained that students
should talk with their parents to
determine if they're covered by
their policy. If they're covered,
it's important to know exactly the
amount of coverage provided,
and to supplement it, if
necessary.
Next, says Raim, students
should become familiar with the

coverage and limitations of services provided by the college or
university. While students may
have access to a college health
facility or infirmary, the extent of
medical coverage can be limited.
To select the right student
health plan—one with year-round
benefits—Raim offered several
guideline. Most importantly, he
said, students should consider a
health plan that picks up where
college infirmaries and clinics
leave off, such as the Blue Cross
and Blue Shield of Maryland Student Health Plan.
The Blue Cross and Blue Shield
Student Health Plan is available
to full-time students taking nine
credit hours or more from ages
19-26. Maryland residents attending an accredited college or
university anywhere in the world,
or non-residents attending such a
school in Maryland, are eligible
for the plan.
Raim suggested students and
parents look for a health plan that
provides certain basic benefits.
He stressed that they should be
aware that, while other plans pay
only a fixed amount per day for
hospital room and board, general
nursing services and other
hospital costs, the Blue Cross and
Blue Shield plan covers most of
these expenses in full.
One other item Raim suggested
is that students look for coverage
that not only provides for them
while at school, but one that also
travels with them wherever they
go.
Applications for the Student
Health Plan are available at college bookstores or student health
centers. For more information
about the plan, call 296-7600 in
the Baltimore metropolitan area,
or toll-free, 1-800-992-2308.
This article was provided as a
service of Blue Cross and Blue
Shield of Maryland.

Unbeaten streak continues as Hooters make up ground to tie for first in the MAC
"We're really playing good
soccer now," smiled first year
coach John Haus. "Our defense
has pulled itself together and has
only given up one goal in the last
four games," he enthuses.
The truth is that the Johns
Hopkins University soccer team
went into this weekend's game
against Dickinson a much improved team over the one that
opened the season with a
lackluster win, followed by two
defeats in a tournament at
Elizabethtown.
The Blue Jays now have a
streak of 5 games without tasting
defeat.(There were 4 wins and a
1-1 tie with Haverford since the
tournament losses). Although the
Middle Atlantic Conference
season has barely begun, Hopkins
is tied for first place with Swarthmore for the time being. The
week ahead should bring a clearer
picture of the league race.
Overall, the team record is 5-2-1.
"One of the things that makes
me feel good," continues Haus,
"is the fact that we have done
well in spite of a number of injuries. All the injuries occurred
to defense players, yet our last
two games were shut-outs."
Tr -captain and sweeper Steve
Gallo (Westhersfield, CT)pulled
a hamstring two weeks ago and
is still out. Senior Staunton
Golding (Annandale, VA) had
been starting at fullback, but a
knee injury has kept him out of
action for 10 days. And
sophomore fullback Billy Hart

(Columbia, MD) sprained his
ankle early in the last game,
although he should be back this
week.
Coach Haus gives strong credit
to junior Matt Lawrence, one of
the four Denver, CO area boys on
the squad, for his play in taking
over as sweeper after Gallo's injury. "Matt Lawrence is a natural
leader," said Haus. "The players
respect him, he does a great job
of organizing the defense. And
the players recognize he is
smart."
Leading scorer on the Blue Jay
squad is Grenville Jones, a senior
and tri-captain from Randolph,
NJ who has 4 goals and 4 assists.

his 8 scores. "He works to get the
ball and plays with intensity. He
puts a lot of pressure on the opposing defense players."
Second leading scorer is Junior
Craig Weinstein (Silver Spring,
MD) who has 2 goals and 4
assists. Weinstein and Jones are
the front-line players in the 2-4-4offensive set-up.
The unsung hero, according to
Haus, is the third tri-captain,
senior midfielder Kevin Flynn
(Columbia, MD). Flynn has
scored only one goal, "but he is
a hard worker who leads by example." Coach Haus also singled out junior midfielder Andy
Nicholas (Silver Spring, MD)as
a person who is key to the offense
as well as defense. Eric Shaw
(Denver, CO) is the goalie who
has made 42 saves in 8 games.

Brambling on a Twin killing again
by P. Sean Bramble
OK, OK, I'll try this week to
stop venting my spleen at Edward
Bennett Williams and instead
focus on the business at hand,
namely, the World Series. And,
following the dictum of Martin
Luther to "go and sin bravely, •'
I shall fearlessly offer my World
Series predictions.
Actually, that would be
"World Series prediction" except for the fact that Whitey Herzog just wouldn't let the Giants
win in time for me to write this.
So I'll have to offer two sets of
predictions -- one for each NL
team against the Minnesota
Tigers. I mean the Detroit Twins.
Well, you know what I mean.
It's just that I have difficulty
believing that the Minnesota
Twins have won the pennant. But
they have. and I must admit they
have earned the right to represent
the ragtag AL West, as well as
the Toronto Blue Jays, Detroit
Tigers, Milwaukee Brewers, and
New York Yankees, all of whom
finished with better records than
the Twins.
Anyway. to prepare my predictions I used the "World Series
Prediction System" invented by
Bill James and presented in his
1984 Baseball Abstract. To keep

the explanations short, its a
series of thirteen rules which,
when applied to post-season
match-ups, correctly identifies
the winner 70 percent of the time.
That means it's not foolproof, but
it's not your roommate's pick,
either. So I ran comparisons for
both match-ups, and here's what
I got:
17-it'ins vs. Giants—This promises to be an exciting matchup,
as these two teams are more
closely matched than I might have
thought. Their offensive indicators are about even, but it's
a dearth of second-line pitching
that will probably doom the
Twins. I can just see Blyleven or
Viola getting knocked out in the
third and Tom Kelly turning
to. . . Les Straker? Joe Niekro?
Maybe it won't happen that
way, hut you have to remember
that Kelly is relying upon three
proven pitchers (Viola, Blyleven,
and Reardon), plus the erratic fat
man (sorry. Juan). Anyway, the
system gives the Giants the edge.
and I would go ahead and pick the
Giants in seven.
Twins vs. Car(linals—
Absolutely no contest. The Cardinals are a terrific team from top
to bottom. They're having trouble beating the Giants because
they're the kind of team the Cards

would have trouble defeating, but
if they make it to the World
Series, they'll smear the Twins.
I mean, the Twins will be so far
out of their depth they'll need a
bathyscape to survive.
And if Clark comes hack, go
for the Cards in four. Without
him the Cardinals should still do
well, and since the system picks
the Cardinals to win handily, I'd
go with the Redbirds in five.
A few notes: Did you know
that before this year, Doyle Alexander's record in postseason play
was 0-3
with
a 7.65
ERA?. . . Before 1987, Uribe and
Thompson had a combined .256
average on grass; on turf,
.216...Of all active regular
ballplayers. the one with the
highest lifetime batting average
against left-handed pitchers is
Kirby Puckett. . . Joe Niekro has
a career ERA of 0.00 in
postseason play: two starts, 18 innings. 0.(X) ERA. and no wonlost record. . . Why is Sal Butera
still in the major leagues?
ANSWER TO LAST WEEK'S
TRIVIA QUESTION: Why, Cy
Young. of course. He was 41
years and 3 months "young."
THIS WEEK'S TRIVIA
QUESTION: Who was the lsat
Minnesota Twin to be named
Rookie of the Year?
Enjoy the Series!

Everything you wanted and
didn't want to know about BIA
by Jim ComoIli
Since there is actually enough
BIA news to fill a whole article,
I'd better skip the sarcasm and
begin. A busy BIA weekend
begins with the singles tennis
tournament being played both
Saturday and Sunday. The
schedule should be posted today
in the A.C. down by the cage,
and should any problems arise,
call Jim at 366-0964. The 2.2
mile BIA roadrace is going to be
held on Sunday, October 18.
Since no schedule is needed, entrants (2 allowed per dorm, independent or frat) should meet in
front of the Athletic Center at
10:30 a.m. Anyone with questions call Heather (yes, we found
her) at 467-1724. BIA flag football also continues this weekend,
and a new schedule (minus the
pitiful forfeiting teams) with a
few more games for each team
will be forthcoming.
Results of the racquetball tournament were miraculously
recovered, so here they are. In
the mixed frat and independent
bracket, Wawa placed first with
ATO and Phi Psi coming in second and third respectively. As
far as the dorms go, Clark captured first and Building A took second. To all teams, make an attempt to keep track of your point
totals (including participation
points) so that when I mess them
up you can come yell at me.
Although the fall lax tournament is postponed (due to lact of

field space and concern for windhsheilds), other BIA events are
on the horizon (they are there,
really). The BIA volleyball
season starts on October 26 and
teams are asked to sign up by 5
p.m. on Monday, October 19. If
there are problems or questions,
call Cary at 338-5702 (since he
lives in Bldg. B he can really use
the attention). The BIA bicycle
race is scheduled to occur on Sunday, October 25, so find a person (or two) that can ride and get
into it. Details are not available
but try to enter before the week
is out.

I'd like to thank the NewsLetter for that fine headline and
the lovely stuffed bluejay in a tree
which accompanied my article
last week, but let's hold back on
the favors next time. Now the
routine part, every Friday at
12:30 p.m. in the Little Theater
there is a wonderous event—the
BIA meeting. Needless to say,
it's open to the public. For BIA
information, call 889-INFO, and
with anything not covered by the
other phone numbers call Jim at
235-1615.

Tomorrow, fans of the Hopkins

woods of Maryland.

see the Hopkins Rugby Football
Club in person, in action, this
Saturday at 1 next to the Athletic
Center.

Soviet philosopher
asserts we cannot
achieve peace by
threatening war
by James Frost
Soviet philosophers are currently facing "hard times in the
USSR" because of changes in
cultural, philosophical, and
political thinking since 1985,
claimed Vladimir Mshvenieradze
to a crowd of twenty students and
professors Monday.
Mshvenieradze is the deputy
director of the Institute of
Philosophy at the Soviet
Academy of Sciences. He spoke
in
the
Department
of
Philosophy's seminar room,
along with Soviet philosopher
Boris Grushin, as part of a
philosophical exchange group in
the United States.
Three more Soviet philosophers were scheduled to
speak, according to Department
of Philosophy Chairman Jerome
Schneewind, who organized the
seminar. Their flights, however,
were unexpectedly late, he said,
so they flew directly to
Washington, D.C.
Schneewind said, "About a
year ago, a group of American
philosophers, eight of us, went to
the Soviet Union to hold discussions on justice and liberty with
members of the Institute of
Philosophy at the Soviet
Academy of Sciences. We are
now witnessing the beginning of
the Soviet visit to the United
States."
Mshvenieradze said that he and
his colleagues had tried to be
critical of the papers presented by
the American philosophers, but
found so much in common with
regard to thoughts on justice and
freedom.
"Free society is not something
given by God, but something that
the individuals must create,"he
said. "Every type of society has
its own understanding of freedom
and justice."
He added that man is forced to
look at freedom and justice in a
drastically new way in the nuclear
age. "The Roman way of getting
peace does not work today, "he
said. "We cannot have peace by
threatening war.
"Freedom and justice are as
old as when the first human being first started to think, " he
said. "The type of justice and
freedom always depended on the
type of society."
Mshvenieradze claimed to
agree with his American colleagues on three main points.
First, "justice can be understood
as the proper balance between
liberty and equality." Second,
"justice has to protect freedom."
Finally, "we have to come to a
common understanding of
justice."
He strongly differed with the
American philosophers by making three further points.
First, he declared that the
topics of justice and freedom
should be viewed "from all possible sides,"including economic,

judicial, political, psychological,
and social.
Second, he claimed that justice
and freedom must be applied to
every individual in society. "It
should not be a freedom and
justice for elite, " he said. "It
should be freedom and justice for
everybody absolutely everybody.,
Third, he insisted that although
we must "still have in mind that
theory and history are indispensible, we cannot elaborate a good
theory only by theoretical
analysis of previous theories. We
should always test our theory
upon reality."

Hopkins sixteenth in survey
WASHINGTON, October 16-The nation's
college and university presidents have named
Stanford University the best national university
in America, according to U.S. News & World
Report's third biennial survey of American higher
education released today.
Stanford University was named best in the
country for the second time, edging out Harvard,
Yale, and Princeton. Chosen by more than half
of the national university presidents completing
the survey, the "Big Four" enjoy worldwide
reputations for the quality of their teaching,
facilities, research, and students. Stanford
came out ahead of the pack-eighteen percent
of the nearly 17,000 applicants for 1,500 places
in the freshman class had 4.0 grade-point
averages. They tend to choose Stanford
because of its "gentler weather" and its "less
intense atmosphere."
U.S. News asked 1,329 college
presidents-764 presidents, or almost sixty percent, answered the survey-to select the ten
schools providing the "best" undergraduate
education from among those classified in the
same category as their own.
The schools were divided into nine separate
categories based on the 1987 classification of
institutions of higher education assembled by the
Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of
Teaching in Princeton, N.J. Presidents were requested to take into consideration cohesiveness
of curriculum, quality of teaching, relationship
between faculty and students and the atmosphere of learning fostered by the campus.
Among the 204 schools in the national university category, Stanford was selected by 65.5 percent of the presidents, followed by Harvard (64.5
percent), Yale (62.7 percent), and Princeton
(52.7 percent).

Maintaining Policy
A proposal was brought before the Committee on Undergraduate Studies(CUS)and
discussed at Student Council this week
which makes changes to the present
Add/Drop policy. According to the nowexistent policy, students may add or drop
classes up until the eighth week of the
semester.
The proposed new policy would move
the add deadline to the second week of the
semester, and drop date would be moved
to the sixth week. This drastic change, supported by Associate Dean of Arts and
Sciences P. Kyle McCarter, was offered in
an attempt to keep some students from using the present system to control their grade
point averages and reserving space in more
classes than their schedules allow.
The Council has developed a counterproposal in response to this. Although it is
only a tentative one, this proposal offers an
add deadline even later than the one
presently in effect. Council members
believe that their plan would be more effective than McCarter's because it would
allow students to fill the spaces left in certain classes after the final drop deadline.
While the Council's proposal needs some

refinements, its principle certainly addresses the needs of student more appropriately than McCarter's.
Many students attend classes unofficially until places become available; sometimes
this is not until four or five weeks into the
semester— often after the first midterm. A
two-week dealine is a restrictively early
one. It would permanently close students
out of classes long before others had to drop
them; by the same token, it would keep
students from dropping classes if they had
no possibility of adding other classes. In the
long run, it would limit some of the flexibility students enjoy early in the year.
Student Council President Scott FitzGerald encouraged students to attend next
Wednesday's Council meeting and express
their opinions about McCarter's proposal.
If the Council's overwhelming disapproval
of the plan is indicative of student opinions
in general, then we hope FitzGerald will
have a solid turnout on Wednesday. It is
imperative that McCarter and the Administration hear the students' views before
they make such a critical change in the
undergraduate program.

A Look at Numbers
The soon to be released U.S. News &
World Report survey of college presidents
shows that Hopkins has been ranked sixteenth in its category, national universities.
The ranking is surprisingly indicative of
Hopkins. It suggests the good and the bad,
but most of all it tries to correlate and quantify Hopkins' uniqueness.
While Hopkins is extremely wellrespected nationally in a number of fields,
the criteria evaluated shed light on why the
ranking is, in comparison to some of these
programs, quite low. The college presidents
were asked to take into consideration the
cohesiveness of the curriculum, the quality of teaching, the relationship between
faculty and students, and the atmosphere
of learning fostered by the campus.
These are the kinds of topics with which
Hopkins undergrads are notoriously discontent. Regarding in particular the faculty's
concern, manifested in time and attitude,
for students, undergraduates have
substantial—and valid—complaints.
The problems regarding faculty/student
relationships and curriculum are being addressed. P. Kyle McCarter Jr., the
associate dean of the School of Arts and
Sciences, is responsible for an intensive

department self-evaluation to take place this
year. Despite the apparent idealism of the
suggestion, this quantified interpretation of
our performance in the given criteria might
provide an impetus. Hopkins, by taking the
ranking for various programs as seriously
as it does, might learn to take great pride
in any future escalation in the ranks.
The ranking of sixteen falls in a range
that reflects a dichotomy. Considering the
problems in curriculum and student/faculty relations that are so apparent, the ranking is still quite high.
A somewhat legitimate response is that
Hopkins is ranked so high because other institutions in its category face comparable
problems and limitations. Although this
thought answers the question somewhat, it
avoids Hopkins' attitude toward education.
Hopkins' strength lies in its independent
study opportunities. Those opportunities,
including the ability to work on an individual basis with faculty starting freshman
year, are by far more abundant than
students realize.
The ranking, which is both high and yet
not high enough, brings out the strengths
in Hopkins. A surprisingly astute survey,
if we pay attention to the numbers.

today.

contributed; to the rest of you
geeks . . .happy singing!

music. The Fall Fest, which took
place under rainy afternoon skies
on the Gilman quad, was designed to keep students on campus
over the Fall Break weekend.
Despite poor attendance in the
past, Fall Fest I-987 was successful in attracting the student
population, predominantly upperclassmen, for various
reasons—some of which had little to do with Fall Fest itself.

most influential factor in its success this year. Organizers of the

idea because people can come and
go when they want without being
obligated to stay for certain
activities."
The casual format of Fall Fest,
however, was unsettling to certain freshmen used to the planned activities of Orientation.

cleared up though, more people
have stopped by."

religious holidays had an indirect
effect on the attendance at the
event. Said freshman Jonathan
Kurtz, "Many students have been
away for Rosh Hashana, Yom
Kippur, and Succot which took
place just this past week. Now a
lot of us want to be back here this
weekend to see our friends and to
see Fall Fest." FitzGerald was

popularity of the event. "I know

After weeks of waiting and
hoping, the Grad Club is finally
opening. With new, limited
hours, Monday through Friday,
9:00 p.m. to 1:00 a.m., the club,
featuring Strange Desire, will
celebrate it's grand opening on a
trial basis.
Though organized slightly differently, the Grad Club will
basically be the same as ever, offering a selection of food ranging
from gyros to pizzas, and beer,
wine, sodas and hot drinks. The
menu was thanged this year to
allow only one pdtrson to serve
and cook at the same time. •
The late reopening and changes
in structure (such as only one person working at a time, and the
limited hours) are due to past
financial difficulties. According
to financial coordinator for student activities Shelly Albrecht,
the school is trying to avoid further losses of money.
Part of the new policy will include only allowing people over
21 in when bands are playing,
which Shelly hopes, will be most
Fridays. Other days, though,
anyone will be admitted. Shelly

stresses that this is not unfair,
since the club is really aimed at
graduate students. If the club is
to be successful, she says, it will
have to be attended by graduate
students.
Shelly also plans, with
managers Norma Perez and Dan
Dubelman, to have promotional
specials, such as certain food
specials during Monday night
football.
The same old juke box and pinball machines grace the over
20-year-old establishment. Decor
still consists of red and white
checked tableclothes and heavy
wood booths. The same wild
mural covers the walls. Even the
prices are the same. For those
who have spent much time there,
nothing will seem different, except that they will not be able to
break the world grad clubbing
record of spending every night
for three weeks in there, since it
won't be open on weekends.
If you've never been to the
Grad Club, though, it's quite an
experience. Stop by and sample
the atmosphere of the place the
City Paper chose as the best uptown neighborhood bar.

PEDAL, from 12
is mainly responsible for
organizing and publicizing
Club rides. The iconoclastic
Cycle
newsletter,
Killers,keeps members abreast
of club developments. The
Club still has a need for a
masseuse. Any one interested
in this position should get in
touch with Gurland.
The vitality of the Club is a
testament to its members enthusiasm. The original Bike
Club became defunct in 1984
after a senior president
absconded with the equipment. The dedication and
perserverence shown by
Anne-Marie Ulrich, Dan
Ninigrin, and Aaron Davis in
the fall of 1985 helped ressurrect a new cycling club. With
the purchase of new equipment(and the establishment of
a security ID system) club
membership flourished. By the
spring of last year, weekend
rides that originally produced
two or three riders were attended by ten or more. At present, the Club's Saturday rides
are a pot-luck, with each
cyclist meeting another and
deciding where they would
like to go. On Sunday, maps
detailing rides of approximately 10,20, and 35 miles are
distributed and the riders split
into groups.
"It's difficult at times to
find the perfect ride for
everyone," says Davis, "but
we try to see to it that no one
gets lost and that everyone has
fun."
When the weather gets chilly, club members still turn out
for the twelve o'clock bell.
With the same dogged dedication (or blatent stupidity)
displayed by the Crew Team
and their five a.m. sculling
sessions, Club members face
wind-chill factors that would
send polar bears running for
shelter, rain that would make
Noah build a little bit faster,
and canines that would make
Cujo look like a French Poodle. Complaints are never
heard though, just the hiss of
115 psi tires on very cold
pavement.
Although the Club includes
many tourists, its core is made
up of a few die-hard racers.
Last weekend at 6 a.m., as the
rest of the sane world slept,
Hopkins Cycling Club
members were congregating at
MSE, shivering as they loaded their thoroughbreds onto
car-racks. Hoping to cash in
on all those weekend rides,
they headed off for the Eastern
Shore Velo Club Cycling
Championship, a two day
stage race composed of a 32
mile road race on Saturday, a
6 mile time trial Sunday morning, and a 21 mile road race
Sunday afternoon.
Saturday's race was five circuits of a six mile loop. The
morning was cool, the road
rolling. Junior Kyu-Tae Lee
was strong throughout the
race, narrowly missing a few
primes (pronounced preems),

which are merchandise or
point prizes given to the winner of a certain lap. Lee faced
a strong sprinter in the final
lap, placing second in a photofinish. Senior Aaron Davis
followed Lee to take third
while senior Tim Reed took
sixth.
A time trial is a race against
the clock, the so-called "race
of truth." Sunday morning
Reed covered the still-dewy
course in a blistering 14:23, a
time which earned him second
place for that stage. Davis
finished fifth, a second behind
the fourth place finisher. Lee
also ran into some bad luck, as
his chain snapped at the turnaround point, sending him into the brush alongside the
road.
All riders seemed to be
recovered for the afternoon
race, as the Hopkins sky-blue
jersies never left the head of
the pack. Reed set the pace for
much of the race, leaving
Davis to sprint for the finish,
where, as Lee had done the,
day earlier, he took second by
half a wheel. Lee crossed the
line in fourth place.
The final results showed
Davis in third place overall,
and Lee in fourth. All in all,
the team had three second
place finishes, one third, one
fourth, and one fifth, a particularly strong showing for
the team's initial race. Juniors
Kendt Eckland and Jeff
Gurland had respectable showings, as did somphomore Udai
Kammula. Freshman Mark
Rubin ran into an amourous
terrier in Sunday's last race,
but escaped the incident
unscathed. All competitors enjoyed themselves, despite the
almost two-hour commute to
the Eastern Shore.
"We'll definitely be stronger
in the spring," said Reed after
the race. Coming up later this
month on the team's schedule
is the Tour of America
Criterium in College Park,
which will take place October
25. November will bring the
Bobby Phillips Criterium at
Lake Montebello, just a few
blocks past Memorial stadium.
The bulk of racing, however,
will take place in the spring.
The team will participate in as
many Eastern Collegiate Cycling Federation (which
Hopkins is a part of)events as
possible. Races are held at
various campuses in the Northeast. The ECCF championships will be held in Vermont
at the end of the season.
Whether racing or just
hanging out, the Bike Club
holds true to its motto: It's better to look good than to be
good. If you'd like to join the
blue-jersies for some high
speed thrills or a tour through
the Maryland countryside,
show up in front of MSE or
call Jeff Gurland. No experience is necessary. Come
out for a spin. The foliage will
be beautiful the next few
weeks and the spandex has
never been tighter!

Well, they tell me that the

One of the albums I received to
review was the latest from
Samantha Fox, the British topless
model turned pop star. A quick
listen revealed nothing new—she
still has no talent. In fact, judging from the sleeve photos and
her lyrical choices("I Can't Get
No Satisfaction," etc.), it has
become quite obvious that the only thing selling this girl is her sex,
which she flaunts quite openly.
Now, this is the nature of the
beast—most girl groups have sold
more on their sex than their talent
(yes, there are exceptions), but
this makes me wonder if maybe
or Tipper doesn't have a point
about that demon rock-and-roll.
By selling themselves like this,
female rockers give a very skewed image to female sexuality.
Now, I have never considered
myself a feminist, but I do find
this is degrading to women. We
find ourselves casting women into
a mold created by these performers, and we expect them to

live up to these expectations—we
want hot nymphos, and that's
what we expect.
Okay, point two: I don't
believe for a minute that rockand-roll carbonates hormones any
more than a good-looking
member of the opposite sex, but
performers of this type sure do
put a lot of emphasis on the sex
act. This in itself might not be a
bad thing, but in this day and age,
emphasizing having sex with wild
abandon seems a bit stupid, considering all the stuff lurking out
there. It would be stupid for performers to start writing songs
about using condoms, but they
should, like any responsible artist, take a few minutes to consider what they're saying.
As for Samantha Fox and her
ilk, I can only conjecture that
they've decided to say something
blatently adolescent, and more
than a little stupid.

Selecting plans for
student insurance
The first few weeks on a college campus are normally
hectic—students jam bookstores,
dorms are invaded and
classrooms must be located. But
there is one very important area
of college life that shouldn't be
overlooked by students during the
scramble—a health plan.
"Medical expenses can run extremely high, and many students
requiring services beyond the
scope of college health centers
will often find themselves with inadequate coverage," said Garry
Raim, director of marketing for
the Blue Cross and Blue Shield of
Maryland Student Health Plan.
According to the latest figures
available from the Health Insurance Association of America,
the average cost per day in a
hospital is $470. An accident or
illness resulting in a two-week
hospital stay could cost in excess
of $6,500. And if surgery is required, the medical bill would
climb even higher.
"Because someone is young
and healthy, the last thing they
are likely to worry about is health
care expenses," said Raim. "But
without quality health insurance
a student could face an unexpected hospital bill—a bill that
could pose a serious financial
setback."
itaim and other health professionals suggest several steps:
"First," he said,' it's important
for students to learn whether they
are protected from the high costs
of hospitalization, emergency and
surgical care."
He explained that students
should talk with their parents to
determine if they're covered by
their policy. If they're covered,
it's important to know exactly the
amount of coverage provided,
and to supplement it, if
necessary.
Next, says Raim, students
should become familiar with the

coverage and limitations of services provided by the college or
university. While students may
have access to a college health
facility or infirmary, the extent of
medical coverage can be limited.
To select the right student
health plan—one with year-round
benefits—Raim offered several
guideline. Most importantly, he
said, students should consider a
health plan that picks up where
college infirmaries and clinics
leave off, such as the Blue Cross
and Blue Shield of Maryland Student Health Plan.
The Blue Cross and Blue Shield
Student Health Plan is available
to full-time students taking nine
credit hours or more from ages
19-26. Maryland residents attending an accredited college or
university anywhere in the world,
or non-residents attending such a
school in Maryland, are eligible
for the plan.
Raim suggested students and
parents look for a health plan that
provides certain basic benefits.
He stressed that they should be
aware that, while other plans pay
only a fixed amount per day for
hospital room and board, general
nursing services and other
hospital costs, the Blue Cross and
Blue Shield plan covers most of
these expenses in full.
One other item Raim suggested
is that students look for coverage
that not only provides for them
while at school, but one that also
travels with them wherever they
go.
Applications for the Student
Health Plan are available at college bookstores or student health
centers. For more information
about the plan, call 296-7600 in
the Baltimore metropolitan area,
or toll-free, 1-800-992-2308.
This article was provided as a
service of Blue Cross and Blue
Shield of Maryland.

soccer now," smiled first year
coach John Haus. "Our defense

only given up one goal in the last
four games," he enthuses.

Hopkins University soccer team
went into this weekend's game
against Dickinson a much improved team over the one that

lackluster win, followed by two
defeats in a tournament at

Brambling on a Twin killing again
by P. Sean Bramble
OK, OK, I'll try this week to
stop venting my spleen at Edward
Bennett Williams and instead
focus on the business at hand,
namely, the World Series. And,
following the dictum of Martin
Luther to "go and sin bravely, •'
I shall fearlessly offer my World
Series predictions.
Actually, that would be
"World Series prediction" except for the fact that Whitey Herzog just wouldn't let the Giants
win in time for me to write this.
So I'll have to offer two sets of
predictions -- one for each NL
team against the Minnesota
Tigers. I mean the Detroit Twins.
Well, you know what I mean.
It's just that I have difficulty
believing that the Minnesota
Twins have won the pennant. But
they have. and I must admit they
have earned the right to represent
the ragtag AL West, as well as
the Toronto Blue Jays, Detroit
Tigers, Milwaukee Brewers, and
New York Yankees, all of whom
finished with better records than
the Twins.
Anyway. to prepare my predictions I used the "World Series
Prediction System" invented by
Bill James and presented in his
1984 Baseball Abstract. To keep

the explanations short, its a
series of thirteen rules which,
when applied to post-season
match-ups, correctly identifies
the winner 70 percent of the time.
That means it's not foolproof, but
it's not your roommate's pick,
either. So I ran comparisons for
both match-ups, and here's what
I got:
17-it'ins vs. Giants—This promises to be an exciting matchup,
as these two teams are more
closely matched than I might have
thought. Their offensive indicators are about even, but it's
a dearth of second-line pitching
that will probably doom the
Twins. I can just see Blyleven or
Viola getting knocked out in the
third and Tom Kelly turning
to. . . Les Straker? Joe Niekro?
Maybe it won't happen that
way, hut you have to remember
that Kelly is relying upon three
proven pitchers (Viola, Blyleven,
and Reardon), plus the erratic fat
man (sorry. Juan). Anyway, the
system gives the Giants the edge.
and I would go ahead and pick the
Giants in seven.
Twins vs. Car(linals—
Absolutely no contest. The Cardinals are a terrific team from top
to bottom. They're having trouble beating the Giants because
they're the kind of team the Cards

would have trouble defeating, but
if they make it to the World
Series, they'll smear the Twins.
I mean, the Twins will be so far
out of their depth they'll need a
bathyscape to survive.
And if Clark comes hack, go
for the Cards in four. Without
him the Cardinals should still do
well, and since the system picks
the Cardinals to win handily, I'd
go with the Redbirds in five.
A few notes: Did you know
that before this year, Doyle Alexander's record in postseason play
was 0-3
with
a 7.65
ERA?. . . Before 1987, Uribe and
Thompson had a combined .256
average on grass; on turf,
.216...Of all active regular
ballplayers. the one with the
highest lifetime batting average
against left-handed pitchers is
Kirby Puckett. . . Joe Niekro has
a career ERA of 0.00 in
postseason play: two starts, 18 innings. 0.(X) ERA. and no wonlost record. . . Why is Sal Butera
still in the major leagues?
ANSWER TO LAST WEEK'S
TRIVIA QUESTION: Why, Cy
Young. of course. He was 41
years and 3 months "young."
THIS WEEK'S TRIVIA
QUESTION: Who was the lsat
Minnesota Twin to be named
Rookie of the Year?
Enjoy the Series!

Everything you wanted and
didn't want to know about BIA
by Jim ComoIli
Since there is actually enough
BIA news to fill a whole article,
I'd better skip the sarcasm and
begin. A busy BIA weekend
begins with the singles tennis
tournament being played both
Saturday and Sunday. The
schedule should be posted today
in the A.C. down by the cage,
and should any problems arise,
call Jim at 366-0964. The 2.2
mile BIA roadrace is going to be
held on Sunday, October 18.
Since no schedule is needed, entrants (2 allowed per dorm, independent or frat) should meet in
front of the Athletic Center at
10:30 a.m. Anyone with questions call Heather (yes, we found
her) at 467-1724. BIA flag football also continues this weekend,
and a new schedule (minus the
pitiful forfeiting teams) with a
few more games for each team
will be forthcoming.
Results of the racquetball tournament were miraculously
recovered, so here they are. In
the mixed frat and independent
bracket, Wawa placed first with
ATO and Phi Psi coming in second and third respectively. As
far as the dorms go, Clark captured first and Building A took second. To all teams, make an attempt to keep track of your point
totals (including participation
points) so that when I mess them
up you can come yell at me.
Although the fall lax tournament is postponed (due to lact of

field space and concern for windhsheilds), other BIA events are
on the horizon (they are there,
really). The BIA volleyball
season starts on October 26 and
teams are asked to sign up by 5
p.m. on Monday, October 19. If
there are problems or questions,
call Cary at 338-5702 (since he
lives in Bldg. B he can really use
the attention). The BIA bicycle
race is scheduled to occur on Sunday, October 25, so find a person (or two) that can ride and get
into it. Details are not available
but try to enter before the week
is out.

I'd like to thank the NewsLetter for that fine headline and
the lovely stuffed bluejay in a tree
which accompanied my article
last week, but let's hold back on
the favors next time. Now the
routine part, every Friday at
12:30 p.m. in the Little Theater
there is a wonderous event—the
BIA meeting. Needless to say,
it's open to the public. For BIA
information, call 889-INFO, and
with anything not covered by the
other phone numbers call Jim at
235-1615.

Tomorrow, fans of the Hopkins

at home when HRFC does battle
with Mason-Dixon at 1 p.m. on

Athletic Center. After the game,

following losses to Mason-Dixon

weekend, the Club travels to
Turnpike exit 16 to take on Jersey
Shore on Halloween, before

returning to play Rocky Gorge on
November 7 somewhere in the
woods of Maryland.

Wednesdays, and Fridays at 4
p.m. on Garland Field; new
players are always welcome and
further information about the
Club can be obtained by calling
its emperor, Jay Harris, at
366-4958. The team includes a
bunch of players who like to see
their names in the paper—but
you'll have to wait for the Rugby'
Pullout Issue if you want to sed
'em. But, hell, why wait? Come
see the Hopkins Rugby Football
Club in person, in action, this
Saturday at 1 next to the Athletic
Center.
